chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess someone with a red eye?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Assessment of a person with red eye involves taking a history and performing an examination to help identify the underlying cause, and any red flags for a serious underlying condition. 

  • Take a history, including:
    • Onset and duration of symptoms.
    • If symptoms are unilateral or bilateral.
    • Any perceived visual changes.
    • Pain.
    • Foreign body sensation.
    • Discharge.
    • Photophobia.
    • Whether the person wears contact lenses.
    • Any history of chemical exposure or trauma.
    • Any similar episodes in the past.
    • Past medical history of hypertension or any medical conditions associated with the causes of red eye, for example, connective tissue disorders.
    • Medication (for example use of eye drops). If subconjunctival haemhorrage is suspected determine if the person is taking an anticoagulant.
  • Perform an examination:
    • If perforation of the globe is suspected (for instance in ocular trauma or as a complication of scleritis), do not palpate the eye - arrange for urgent ophthalmology assessment.
    • Check the person's visual acuity.
    • Assess for evidence of facial trauma.
    • Check for any discharge from the eye(s).
    • Examine the lids for trichiasis, entropion or ectropion.
    • Examine the conjunctiva, including the tarsal surface. If foreign body is a possibility, the upper lid should be everted to check for a sub-tarsal foreign body. 
    • Check the pattern of redness. Ciliary flush, where the limbal vessels (where the cornea meets the sclera) are injected, is seen in more serious causes of red eye, such as anterior uveitis and corneal causes. 
    • Perform fluorescein examination. If the cornea stains this can be an indication that a corneal abrasion or ulcer is present.
    • Check pupil reactions, using the brightest light source possible.
      • Check if the person is photophobic.
      • Observe pupil size and shape.
      • Check direct and consensual pupillary reflexes.
    • Check the person's blood pressure, if subconjunctival haemorrhage is suspected.
  • Document the history and findings of eye examinations (including negative findings). This is particularly important when management of a unilateral red eye is going to take place in primary care.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The information on the clinical assessment of a person with red eye is largely based on expert opinion in review articles [Wong, 2014; Dunlop, 2015; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
